instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with ‚Äú_EN‚Äù , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says ‚ÄúBKL‚Äù before ‚Äú_EN‚Äù. ‚ÄúBKL‚Äù sounds short for ‚ÄúBACKLIGHT‚Äù, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The ‚Äú_R‚Äù suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the ‚Äú_L‚Äù  suffix.
definitions.BKLT_SD: What is BKLT_SD? BKLT_SD is a pin of the LED driver that goes to the voltage divider that feeds the gate of the transistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H and the backlight circuit. The LED driver will short this pin to ground when backlight circuit is ready to turn on. Prerequisites are 1) it is told to turn on via enable signal, the screen has communicated with the LED driver 2) current sensing circuit is working 3) does not detect an over-current situation such as the backlight power rail being shorted to ground.
definitions.PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT? PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT is PPBUS_G3H backlight voltage entering the backlight boost circuit once the transistor has been told to allow it through. .
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see ‚Äú_EN‚Äù, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, ‚ÄúEDP_BKLT‚Äù which stands for ‚Äúembedded displayport backlight‚Äù is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
No backlight issue all resistors on circuit are good besides <RESISTOR>R8432</RESISTOR> which should be 150k but it's 24.2k. Also I get diode mode on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> 0.50 which might be a shorted Cap? In the past on the same laptop I had <CAPACITOR>C8471</CAPACITOR> burned but maybe happened again?

Thanks :D

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
"I get diode mode on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> 0.50"
Doesn't look like short; post reverse reading too.
You can compare with the readings from similar board.

What about <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> voltage (LCD connected)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
"Did you try known good LCD assembly?"
Backlight adjust comes through I2C bus from T-CON board.

"Test in diode mode:
    Connect positive probe of the multimeter (red) to ground and touch the test point with black probe.
    Sometime (rarely) we need to test in reverse direction."
Lot more information on that thread...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
I replaced <CAPACITOR>C8467</CAPACITOR> now i have diode mode 1.1  

The only resistor which is not showing correct value is <RESISTOR>R8432</RESISTOR> and instead of 150k it shows 33k and diode mode on it is 0.700

<RESISTOR>R9827</RESISTOR> is 7.4k

I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR> also.

On <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR> i have 5v on pin 5 and pin 18.

Pin 11 12v
pins 15,16,17 0v

Any suggestions please?

Also if someone knows if the flex cable for backlight on the lcd is broken will it still boost and give voltage on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>.

Thanks guys

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
Depends is backlight out is shorted, or interrupted.
Getting 55V denotes no contact with LEDS strip.
0V can be short, or backlight circuit blocked for other reason.

"pins 15,16,17 0v"
So missing <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL>; <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> too?
Check <RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>-53; strange to get 0V at pins 15 & 16...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R8452</RESISTOR> and  <RESISTOR>R8453</RESISTOR> are 1.3k 

This morning i measured again and i have 3.3v on pin17, and on pins 15/16 i have 4.6v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R8450</RESISTOR>-53  refers to 4 resistors.
However, all seems good, if get 4.6V there now.
Still no volt at <DIODE>D8410</DIODE> output?

Do you have image for sure?
3V3/<SIGNAL>5V_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> steady voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message: SOLVED!  <CAPACITOR>C8462</CAPACITOR> was the issue <SIGNAL>O_O</SIGNAL>:ROFLMAO:ü•≥

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message:
If PWM duty cycle changes when press backlight keys, denotes the PCH works good.
The LCD assembly doesn't receive correctly this signal, or you have a problem between <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> and LCD assembly.
Check for reaction on SCL/SDA lines at same time with PWM signal.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - No Backlight
threads.message: All is good now works fine <CAPACITOR>C8462</CAPACITOR> had internal crack which didn't show visually and also there was no short but while I was replacing the diode and other ICs it cracked and showed I just replaced it and it worked :) Thank you very much for your help
